channel.title: Qt > wxWidgets
channel.description:
[i](continued from [url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,381597.msg2873702.html#msg2873702]here[/url])[/i] Most of my beef with wxWidgets lies in the core component wxAui, which is a docking manager for the library. It is quite amateur, and I have first-hand experience of that, and since docking is a functionality used in many applications, this is not true:
wxWidgets can be used perfectly for almost any kind of program
While we're talking about false statements, let's throw some more up on the board:
QT is not C++
It also means that since millions of people use these controls, it is extremely unlikely to find a significant bug in one of them.
QT on the other side renders the controls itself, trying to imitate native controls, being ... more prone to look & feel discrepancies
The primary reason I switched to Qt from wxWidgets was because wxWidgets does focus more on WINAPI than the other platforms supported by the "cross-platform library," which leads to look & feel discrepancies between versions of the application you're trying to make. For example, it doesn't do actual MDI in Linux, it just uses tabbing as an alternative. You're right, wxWidgets uses native controls whenever possible, even if it leads to discrepancies; they seem to honor speed above the cross-platform aspect of a "cross-platform library." Therefore Qt does a better job at achieving this goal. PS - hi, zstars

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

I’ve used GTK# with MonoDevelop, the form designer is quite good, and the API is very easy to understand.

Read full topic

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

seand:

Please tell me you’re not this stupid, qauters. You can’t do bug testing by watching a video of someone playing with the control. You can, however, do bug testing by playing with the control. Wait, didn’t I already say that?

Obviously but everything in the movie goes smooth as it should be, neither are their any bug reports on the internet (other then a few years old).
So to be honest it shows ok.

Read full topic

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

seand:

[quote]There are two things that can be called docking.

Yes, I meant both when talking about a docking manager. The control itself also has to be scalable for the number of items it controls. For example, if you look at the wxAui sample that comes with the library, you see it can dock a lot of things, and they have the different properties that you can set for docked/undocked windows. More importantly, if you play around with this sample, you should probably start to see at least a bug or two (I haven’t worked on it in over a year, so maybe they fixed everything). In any case, you can’t tell how well a control works by looking at a screenshot of it.[/quote]
True, screenshots show nothing. The video below it does:
http://videos.kirix.com/labs/2009-06-30-labs-wxaui-demo/2009-06-30-labs-wxaui-demo.htm

Read full topic

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:11, topic:289518”]those licenses are GNU LGPL for Qt and wxWindows Library Licence for wxWidgets.

by the way what do you guys think of GTK+ ?[/quote]

GTK+ itself is C which kinda means I’d never use it, however GTKmm (Which is a C++ wrapper for it) is somewhat popular and said to have a better C++ API than both wxWidgets and QT, but I’ve never really tried it myself yet.

Read full topic

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

There are two things that can be called docking.
Yes, I meant both when talking about a docking manager. The control itself also has to be scalable for the number of items it controls. For example, if you look at the wxAui sample that comes with the library, you see it can dock a lot of things, and they have the different properties that you can set for docked/undocked windows. More importantly, if you play around with this sample, you should probably start to see at least a bug or two (I haven't worked on it in over a year, so maybe they fixed everything). In any case, you can't tell how well a control works by looking at a screenshot of it.

zstars, there are a couple problems with your lists. The first, most prominent thing is that it’s way too short and shallow; you didn’t scratch the surface of a comparison between the two libraries, because in order to do that, we have to compare the different components and how well they work together and how much additional functionality is provided. And there has to be evidence. You keep saying that Qt is “more prone to native OS look & feel discrepancies,” but I haven’t yet seen any myself.

Oh, and to anyone asking about GTK+: I’ve never used it, and I know zstars is a wxWidgets fanboy and I’m a Qt fanboy so I figured we’d try to finally settle this.

Read full topic

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:11, topic:289518”]those licenses are GNU LGPL for Qt and wxWindows Library Licence for wxWidgets.

by the way what do you guys think of GTK+ ?[/quote]
I tried it at first, but on that moment I used glade to build the GUI but I couldn’t enjoy it. After that I tried wxFormBuilder and figured out how it worked, so I sticked with it.
However I might understand Glade now, because I was used to visual studio alike GUI builders (easy to dock/align etc) while these GUI builders require sizers etc. Which isn’t bad, but it is annoying if you never did it before

Read full topic

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

So as I see it, in conclussion:

QT

[ul][li]Trolltech founded in 1994.[/li]
[li]Less prone to discrepancies between different platforms.[/li]
[li]More prone to native OS look & feel discrepancies[/li]
[li]Less efficient (Non-native controls, more virtual functions)[/li]
[li]Non-standard language (Requires a non-standard C++ preprocessor)[/li]
[li]More restrictive license[/li][/ul]

wxWidgets

[ul][li]First version in 1992.[/li]
[li]More prone to discrepancies between different platforms.[/li]
[li]Less prone to native OS look & feel discrepancies[/li]
[li]More efficient (Controls native whenever possible, less virtual usage)[/li]
[li]Standard C++[/li]
[li]Friendly license (Can be linked statically for free in commercial projects as well)[/li][/ul]

Read full topic

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

seand:

[quote]It does on visual studio?

I find your attempts to contribute to this subject amusing, given your lack of real, supporting evidence. Until you decide to come back with something substantial, stay at the kids’ table, drink your juice, and let the adults talk for a while. For the future, you may also want to learn what functionality a docking manager actually provides.[/quote]

He was right though, thats exactly what “dock” means in the context of every Windows-based toolkit I’ve used. No idea about qt/wx.

Read full topic

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

seand:

[quote]It does on visual studio?

I find your attempts to contribute to this subject amusing, given your lack of real, supporting evidence. Until you decide to come back with something substantial, stay at the kids’ table, drink your juice, and let the adults talk for a while. For the future, you may also want to learn what functionality a docking manager actually provides.[/quote]
There are two things that can be called docking.
One: the thing I said.

Two: Able to dock it on realtime by moving it etc. Which you meant (which I didn’t check, which was my mistake).
Still if I look at: http://www.kirix.com/labs/wxaui/screenshots.html it looks to be working perfectly.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

seand:

[quote]Because you don’t know how to create a GUI with wxwidgets doesn’t mean it’s bad.

I appreciate your lack of faith in me, but I assure you, after seeing your horrible UI for “qbot,” I am better at it than you are.[/quote]
Not really, cause it was meant to be that way and isn’t optimized yet.

Docking means controls stay to a certain side of the window/auto size with it right?
No. [/quote] It does on visual studio?

Read full topic

item.title: Qt > wxWidgets
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

(continued from here)

Most of my beef with wxWidgets lies in the core component wxAui, which is a docking manager for the library. It is quite amateur, and I have first-hand experience of that, and since docking is a functionality used in many applications, this is not true:

wxWidgets can be used perfectly for almost any kind of program

While we’re talking about false statements, let’s throw some more up on the board:

QT is not C++
It also means that since millions of people use these controls, it is extremely unlikely to find a significant bug in one of them.
QT on the other side renders the controls itself, trying to imitate native controls, being ... more prone to look & feel discrepancies

The primary reason I switched to Qt from wxWidgets was because wxWidgets does focus more on WINAPI than the other platforms supported by the “cross-platform library,” which leads to look & feel discrepancies between versions of the application you’re trying to make. For example, it doesn’t do actual MDI in Linux, it just uses tabbing as an alternative. You’re right, wxWidgets uses native controls whenever possible, even if it leads to discrepancies; they seem to honor speed above the cross-platform aspect of a “cross-platform library.” Therefore Qt does a better job at achieving this goal.

PS - hi, zstars

Read full topic
